review_text: These headphones are unbelievably comfortable, the soft leather helps prevent fatigue, and the sound is very high quality. These have outperformed my skull candy hash in sound quality, battery life, and overall portability. Pairs easily with your phone. Overall a very nice set of headphones.

review_title: Comfortable and ergonomic, great noise cancelling, sounds a little thin
review_text: I like these headphones. I did a side-by-side comparison with the beats solo and found a few key differences. The soundcore headphones are more comfortable and flexible than the beats. The ear cups are also large, which made me almost forget I was wearing them because they fit so nicely on my ear. The controls are plastic buttons, rather than the touch sensors on the beats - so they are not quite as sleek. Soundcore more than makes up for it in comfort though. The noise cancelling is also far superior to the beats. When I have these on, I cannot hear someone talking to me from 3 feet away, even when the volume is only at 50%. The only advantage that the beats have over the soundcore is depth of sound, the quality and crispness of music is definitely not as good in the soundcore as it is in competitors. If I did not have another set of headphones to compare it to, I probably wouldn't notice. Overall I would recommend these, especially for people wearing them for long durations or in especially noisy areas.

These Bluetooth headphones are very comfortable & easy to set up. I can’t wear ear buds or anything that actually goes in the ear canal but the memory foam ear cups fit like a dream & effectively block outside noise. It’s also very easy to adjust the headband for a perfect fit. It was easy to pair with Bluetooth. I have an upcoming flight across country & I look forward to being in my own little world without listening to all the extra noise on the plane. A full charge gives 30-hours of wireless playtime & it has a notification tone when there are only 2 hours of playtime left. My trip is over 12 hours due to layovers & I don’t have to worry about my ear phones going dead. If there was any reason I didn’t have enough juice & no time for a full charge, 5 minutes gives a quick charge for 4 hours of listening. It has Hi-Res Audio for a great sound. I like strong bass in my music & by double pressing the play button it instantly strengthens the bass output. The headphones have a travel bag that has a pocket with a velcro closure to hold the AUX cable & & micro USB cable. The manual is easy to read & understand. I think the hardest thing for me was seeing the markings on the tiny controls on each earpiece. I haven’t taken any calls, as I’m not accustomed to the buttons, yet. Once I get used to them it’ll come naturally. These are really great headphones, probably the best I’ve seen in quite a while.

The Q20 headphones are some of the better noise cancelling headphones on the market. I've tried several brands and found that the four-microphone setup they use rivals the cancellation capability of my noise cancelling aviation headset which cost as much as a decent used car. That's pretty impressive. The design is comfortable, with the ear cups able to articulate in any direction necessary for a good fit. These might not do well with small people, however- I've got the headband adjusted to the smallest setting and I'm not even a small person. These would likely feel loose on a youngster's head. Sound quality. Therein lies my only criticism. The extra bass circuit is interesting and the overall sound is quite good. There is a noticeable lack of high end, it's just not a crisp sound. MANY headphones are this way, likely to help reduce listening fatigue. Imaging is nowhere near what some headphones are capable of, but those headphones (in my experience) don't have as competent of a noise cancelling capability. I'd rather have the Soundcore headphones on a long airplane trip because of that. I have not tried the microphone and cell phone capability because I use headphones exclusively for music. Overall, I'd give these a thumbs-up as they are a good compromise between sound quality and noise cancellation.

review_title: So comfortable you will forget you are wearing them
review_text: These ear cushions are heavenly. Cushy/soft and large enough to not cramp you ears. The next bit of awesome is the noise cancellation; this is tops for killing ambient noise, (love these on a flight). If the volume is set at a reasonable level you'll still be able to hear when someone is talking to you though. These aren't as great for sound as B&W PX or even something like Beats. The PX really are superb for music; they really add depth to any track I've ever listened to...there's just so much I didn't know I was missing. The Beats, too, are a bit better than these for sound quality. That being said, these are still solid, just less a bit less luxury for audiophiles.

Very nice pair of wireless headphones. They charged quickly and were very easy to pair with my phone. The buttons to adjust the sound are conveniently located and easy to use. The ear pieces are well padded and comfortable and the top part is adjustable to accommodate different head sizes. I’m not an expert but the sound quality seems to be really good/clear. No distortion that I noticed. Extremely pleased with the performance of these

Overall I am satisfied with these. They are comfortable and sound pretty good. The look nice. They fold flat for storage. They come with a bag for storage which is okay but will not protect them. They don't connect smoothly and powering them on is a little glitchy but not a major hindrance. Overall these are good. I have had better and I have had much worse.

When I first put on the Soundcore headphones I had pretty low expectations as I had never heard of the brand, and this is a family which is pretty serious about audio. That said, I was expecting something pretty generic and was pleasantly surprised. The first piece I listened to was acoustic guitar, and the clarity was beautiful. There was no background noise and I could hear the guitar strings clearly. That does not happen often, at least with low end or mid-range headphones. When I test headphones I put them through a broad range of music and listen for a couple of hours as many will improve with burn in. My experience with these was different. I liked them less as I listened longer. I did not notice a significant improvement with burn in, or in fact, much of a change when I used the bass boost button. Now I am not a fan of boosted bass. For one, I prefer a more natural balanced sound. I have also found that on most boosted bass equipment (speakers and headphones) something is lost, sacrificed. The high end and mids are usually lost or just not handled well. A couple of months ago I tried a set in which this was not the case, Sony's mid range boosted bass headphones, where the equalization shift was evident but the highs and mids were lower without having a reduced sound quality. I have tried a lot of headphones this year and purchased several sets. It seems to be the year that bluetooth was really figured out. There are a number of good sets out there and this is not among the best, even in the price range. It is good, better than average, but not as good as any of the Sony's, or Sennheisers. The highs on these are better than most, but the bass is not as good, even with bass boost on. They have nice clarity but do not touch the Sony WH1000s. There is not much of a sound stage. They sounded better with a solo guitar than with a band or orchestra. Stereo and localization is not as good as with a lot of other headphones, and good stereo is something I consider important in audio. That said, these would not work especially well as a gaming set (but they are not presented as such) but they also lack some as audio phones without good separation. My review may be a bit technical for some, but I know that there are a lot of people who do a fair bit of research before they purchase. I am one. The noise cancellation is good, and I do not believe it interferes with the sound (it does on some). I am not sure it is the best. Sony's nopise cancellation is startling. When I tried them we had a thundesrstorm which I was completely unaware of until I took them off and went outside. The noise cancellation on the Soundcore is good but I am not sure it is as good. It may be. I did not have that level of background noise when I tried these so I can not really be sure. They headband is light and pretty comfortable. It does not clamp tightly like some I have tried, did not give me a headache even after wearing them for hours, but I would not call them cushy (like Sennheisers). They are huge! I had to wear them on the smallest setting. These would not work for teens or kids, or even petite adults. The ear cups are padded, and comfortable but the synthetic leather builds up heat pretty quickly. Even wearing them in the evening, in air conditioning, I had to take them off to cool down. That is, I was getting so hot that it was really uncomfortable. I live in Hawaii, and so it is more of an issue here than most places, but it is worth knowing that the material does not breathe and that there is heat build up. They are articulated and fold well which adds to the comfort and fit, and also makes them very mobile. I have given these to my daughter to try because she listens to a different range of music than I do. I may adjust my rating dafter she has tried them. She likes a lot of bass, so I do not expect her to like these better than I did, but I could be wrong. The literature says they use an algorithm to adjust bass and it is possible that it will work better with the music she listens to than what I listen to. In sum, I think these are pretty good mid-range phones. The high end has very nice clarity but the bass is somewhat lacking. I did not find the sound as rich as my Sennheisers, or as precise as my Sony's. The headset is light, adjustable, comfortable. They fold and would be good as a mobile headset. The noise cancellation is good, and I can see wearing these on a city street. All in all I think these are significantly better than average, but not my personal favorites.

review_title: Great sound. Hit or miss on voice.
review_text: I've been using his Beo H7's as, my last pair of headsets, have finally gone kaput. While I like the sound & voice quality on the H7, don't like how firm the ear pieces are. Very dense, almost rock-like foam. If you lie down, they dig. Also, not a fan of Beo's ANC. It had what I call, "Succulating". Sucks the noise out so hard, you're in a vacuum vortex of isolating. Some may like this, I find it makes me feel off balance. So those are the 3 major features where Anker's Q20 excels. - sound quality incredible - pillow soft ear foam - noise cancelling quiets while still letting in removed outside noise. From a safety issue, I prefer to still be aware of noises around me, just don't want them invading my happy place. Challenges of the Q20 - phone quality always clear on my end but listeners complained of static in a variety of situations - the headphones slip, and sometimes fall off, with excessive motion, ie Blink182. - won't pair to soundbar. Only pairs to app related audio where you can click the Q20. All in all, if the current price point really remains at$59, these are a steal. I would pay double that just on the exceptional sound quality & comfort. Perhaps pick up an Aftermarket headband for fit.

review_title: Comfortable, sound cancelling, and good sound!
review_text: These are great. My husband worked a 16 hr shift at work, and they were at half battery life. These cancel sound well in noisy environments, and the sound quality is spot on. They are also extremely comfortable, and easy to pair with any bluetooth. Really a great buy!

Wow! I was impressed by these headphones. Not only do they have clear sound, but they are comfortable for longer listening times. They make listening to something easy even when the train in the valley is going by, or the trash trucks are at work. I don't usually use the noise cancellation since the headphones cancel a lot of noise anyway, but turning on the noise cancellation was astonishing! It cut out so much noise that I didn't know when the AC kicked on and wondered why I suddenly felt my chair vibrate just a little. I can completely understand why there are cautions about using the noise cancellation at times because you really can't hear much! I charged my headphones one week, and it is still fully charged a week later. Of course I don't listen all the time or for hours on end, but it's great that I don't have to charge them all the time. One thing I really like about these, besides the comfort and noise blocking, is the fact that they are wireless. I like to be able to get up and move away from my computer and still keep listening. I'm very glad I got these!

I am thoroughly impressed with these headphones. The sound quality is unbelievable! You can really hear the bass and other sounds that you wouldn’t even notice if you were listening to it in the car or some other way. The ear cups are very comfortable, no pain, even after wearing for a long time. I like the noise-cancelling effect, too. With these on, no one else stands a chance in trying to get my attention. I had an easy time syncing them to my phone. The travel case is a nice extra. And it’s really easy to fold them up and take them with you. I would say that these are perfect for taking to the gym, going for a walk, doing chores around the house, and any other time you want to take a little break from the world!

All I can say is WOW! The sound on these headphones are excellent and has plenty of bass. The noise canceling also works very well. When it's on, I can't hear my wife. ;-) It allows you to fully enjoy what you're listening to. As for comfort, I can't say you forget you're wearing the, but you won't mind having these on for an extended period of time. I didn't suffer the discomfort I felt with other brands after a while. I was able to use them all day, which also says something about the battery life. I highly recommend these headphones.

For the price i was hoping i would get Mid-rage head phones, i own pairs much more expensive than this. THESE ARE AMAZING! You can not hear a thing when you have them on. The sound quality is great and they're really comfortable! I would say the battery life is pretty normal.

review_title: Good price/value ratio. Very comfy. Wish it came with hard case.
review_text: I have uploaded photos of the directions. Took about 3 to 3.5 hours to fully charge with a 5V power output brick over 5 trials. Stated charge time is 3 hours, so this is close. Uses micro USB to charge. They weigh about 260g or about 9.2 ounces without the cord. The bluetooth works about 25 to 30 feet direct line of sight away from my phone. This is pretty typical. It is Bluetooth V 5.0 The battery lasted between 19-23 hours when using bluetooth AND noise cancelling at the same time over 3 trials at a fairly high volume. (These are approximate, I check them every hour or so to see if still running) Bluetooth connecting is easy. The sound is good for listening to pretty much everything, general music, podcasts, videos. I used these to listen to opera with very subtle sound of a glass harmonica and they worked well. Some audiophiles say headphones work better after a burn in of 50 hours, so I left them playing that long while testing the battery endurance. I did not notice a difference. Then again I am not an audiophile. The claimed range of 16 to 22,000 Hz covers more than the normal range of human hearing. 20-20000hz Sensitivity (as in manual) is the range of perfect human hearing. I am old enough that I do not hear above 17,000 Hz, but I can vouch they do go that high (tested them on an online sound generator). Worked well on a plane flight to get rid of the constant monotonous hum of engine noise. These are one of the most comfortable headsets I have had. They work fine on a large head. They fit around even largish ears and stay on without pressing hard on your head. These would be four star headphones except that they are really a good value for the price, which bumps them to 5 stars. I would have liked a hard case, the bag does take up less space but does not provide the protection I like when traveling.

I ordered the Anker Soundcore Life Q20 Headphones because I wanted some Bluetooth headphones. I tried ear buds that work well, but the ear buds don't fit my ears very well. These headphones are great. They have a long battery life [about 30 hours], they fit great, and they produce fantastic sound. They are so comfortable, that I wear them whenever I am working around the house. I wore them while vacuuming the house and they shut out most of the noise of the vacuum. They easily paired with my IPod and Android cell phone. I highly recommend these Anker Soundcore Headphones. They are very good Bluetooth headphones that are worth the price.

review_title: Great range, fit me comfortably, long battery life
review_text: Okay, I think I found my new favorite headphones. These are a nice quality heavy pair of headphones. The joints were the headphones expand for fit are plastic, but the part inside is metal. There is a small book, and I emphasize book, to go along with these headphones, features, directions, trouble shooting, etcetera. Features I personally liked, I got Bluetooth range at over a hundred feet away from the source. Phone on one end of my yard me 100 feet away and I could still hear my music. I got 30 hours of playtime before I had to charge. I like that if need be I can convert these headphones to plug in headphones. The voice is the least annoying of my Bluetooth headphones. The sound is decent for music. The noise cancelling is not like sound deprivation but it feels like you are very far away from surrounding noise. The muff portions actually fit my little ears so well they are inside the muff cups. There are buttons on both sides of the earphones, which can make it easier to navigate if you remember where they are. Things that are not amazing for me, the muff style headphones tend to make voices muffled, like audiobooks and podcasts. There is too much bass or something and the spoken word is harder to hear. I love that this has directions on how to use each function - but it is a lot to remember. It takes a bit to figure it all out and then remember how to use it. (Like for a while instead of skipping the song, I just kept increasing the volume.)
I love these headphones as they help cancel noise out and I like to wear when I fly. They are comfortable and look great. I can’t wait to use again for my next few trips.
Good quality, great sound, easy to sync with device. My only complaint is that they are a little bulkier than I expected.

Another great Soundcore product. Bought these to replace another brand’s that broke and they are so much better! The sound is great and the Bluetooth range is also good for headphones. I like the look better than most other pairs. They're chic and not flashy. Comes with the usual accessories, charging cable, aux cable, carry pouch

review_title: I don't need a fancy Beats. thanks to Anker
review_text: I am sure the sound from Beats is awesome but I don't feel like paying that extra money for the brand. this BT headset by Anker is a good alternative. I don't have the ear to be critical on sound quality (unless it is just really bad) but to me it works good enough for me. I use it to listen to music, play PUBG mobile and the sound is much nicer then the ear piece style headphone. I do wish it comes with a hard storage case (it comes with a PU storage pouch with a smaller velcro pouch within for charging cable). But with the price you pay I won't expect it. I can buy a hard case separately.

I have a number of Anker products at home. Their products are bargain priced and good. However, I was not particularly impressed with these headphones at the price. When I buy headphones, I want them well-made, comfortable, with good sound. I travel for a living. ANC is important to me. I normally use Bose QC35s. Granted, the cost is a lot more, but if you are in need of noise cancelling look somewhere else. These cans are relatively comfortable, but you don't want to wear them for 5+ hours on a plane. For the price, these are good if you want pretty good sound and noise cancelling.

review_title: Good sounding headphones at a great price.
review_text: You can't get better headphones at this price. In fact I like them more than the Beats 2 they are replacing. The finishes aren't as nice but the Q20 seem to be durable nonetheless. They are comfortable to wear on long flights and look sleek in the matte black. Controls are well laid out and easy to use. Sound is clear even at high volume. Highs don't distort. Vocals come through clean. The bass hits but some songs definitely benefit from the Bassup feature. Noise cancelling is really good too, completely blocking out the gardeners next door as I'm writing this. If you know about Anker, you know they make high quality products at very fair prices. These headphones are exactly that. I'd recommend them to family, friends, and random internet people.

review_title: Great for budget conscious buyers, better than expected sound for its price
review_text: I got these noise cancelling headphones mainly because i am on a budget. I wanted something friendly on the pocket that will be useful for both when i’m in the office and outside. I just got these today and i must say sound is great upon testing it the first couple of hours. The pads are comfortable and fit well in my ears. These headphones are worth it based on my initial impressions, i hope its durable enough for my daily commute, only time will tell, will update my review in the next few weeks of further testing

These are really great headphones for the price. They do a great job with noise cancellation, they are comfortable, and the battery life is pretty amazing. I have had them for 3 weeks and only charged them twice. I use them daily. They quickly paired with my phone and have no issues connecting to any other devices.

These headphones are amazing! The noise cancelling feature just blew me away. I enjoy wearing these at work where all of the phone conversations in the cubical maze can drive a person to distraction. Pop these babies on and it is only your music that you hear. The comfort level is also very high, although they seem a little heavy after several hours of wear. Anker, you haven't let me down yet!

review_title: Quality product. As to be expected from Anker
review_text: My first impressions are very good with these headphones. This is my first noise canceling set of headphones and I'm impressed. As to be expected the sound is very good. I'm finding the bass is plenty and possibly a bit too much. The sound is well balanced. For the money, I'd absolutely recommend these.

review_title: Not up to the same level as other Anker products
review_text: Much as I like and use a lot of Anker products, these don't make the cut, and sadly for a lot of aesthetic and clunky design reasons that don't have much to do with their intended functionality. At their core, they provide good ANC, and pleasant - if a tad bassy - sound quality. That said, I'll outline the pros and cons I've observed in using them on the first day: pros: - as noted, nice sound quality, with some reinforcement in the mid-bass frequencies, but the bass is tight, and the mids and highs are mellow - almost inaudible difference to sound quality with noise cancellation enabled, and no notable hiss with ANC on - ANC is not 'make the world go away' levels, and lets some higher frequency sound through; this is great, as I am looking to cancel out midrange and bass sounds like an air conditioner, nearby dogs, and the wearing rumble of airplane engines during long flights - aside from the slightly too small earcups (for my tastes), they are comfortable to wear - neither too loose nor too tight - the various audible and voice prompts are pleasant and at a reasonable volume cons: - big problem: can't charge and listen at the same time - big problem: no ability to use as a phone headset in wired mode (these are headphones only when used with the cable, with no mic available) - the earcup material is too insulative, resulting in unpleasant warmth and sweating under fairly normal circumstances (74F / 45% RH, just sitting at computer doing work, so these would suck for truly warm, humid, and and/or strenuous activity) - when switching ANC on and off, the enhanced bass enables momentarily, which is just sloppy design, and rather jarring - they have stiff creaky hinges and pivots, which is emblematic of inexpensive plastic-on-plastic construction - they have a light but unpleasant chemical smell, which I suspect is from the earcup material, and it's not dissipating any too quickly - a general lack of build refinement - they're nice enough, but the point where the earcup cushions meet the body was wrinkled and unevenly finished All this said, I can't really recommend these, since I think refinement and solid build quality should be reasonable expectations at a $70 price point. If I could give them 3.5 stars, I would, but since their core functionality is great, I'll go with 4 stars instead of 3.

Good sound quality. Noise cancelation could be better. Bluetooth connection randomly drops. Frame creaks as I turn my head, smile, raise an eyebrow, etc... Will be returning because of those last 2 issues.

The Anker Soundcore Life Q20 bluetooth headphones are not what I had expected from a $60 pair of headphones. The sound, the weight, the build quality, and the style are all something to appreciate from this pair of headphones. If you are looking for an expensive sounding pair of headphones for a small price look no further. I will go over all of the specs of the headphones in detail below. General Specs Lets start with what these headphones have to offer. The first item to note about these headphones is that they have bluetooth 5.0. This means their range is ridiculously far and they are low energy data transfer headphones. This is how this pair of headphones packs a 30 hour battery life with all the extras turned on. You can get up to 60 hours if you have a couple features turned off and don't need the volume very loud. They offer noise cancelation and a bass boost function. The padding around your ear is memory foam and my favorite part is that it actually goes around your ear and does not sit on it. They are light and have great sound. The bass is the most impressive part of these headphones. People that do not want bass may want to stay clear of these, but from my testing I really enjoyed the sound. They came with an auxilary cable, charging cable, and a carry pouch. Sound Lets talk about the sound features. The normal sound out of the box is great. if you are bass heavy and want more, they have a bass up feature that really hits. They offer noise canceling to drown out background noises. With bass up and noise canceling on, this is where you get up to 30 hours of battery life. If you don't use these features you can get yourself up to 60 hours of battery. I personally have not needed the noise canceling feature yet and I feel like the sound in normal mode is great. I have easily gotten 40 hours out of these headphones. Louder volumes will affect the battery life as well. If you are an audiofile you may have different opinions than me, but I think these sound as good as Beats or other $100 plus headphones. Build Quality These headphones are light and of course they adjust for different head sizes. They don't feel cheap, which I like. The memory foam cushion around the ears is comfortable. The thing I like the most is the fact that they are big enough to go around my ears instead of sitting on my ears like other headphones do. These are very comfortable well built headphones. Conclusion The Anker Soundcore Life Q20 are a great pair of headphones. In my personal opinion they provide the sound a more expensive option would provide. They are comfortable and have great battery life. I would suggest this pair of headphones to anyone looking for an affordable but expensive sounding pair of headphones.

review_title: Anker Soundcore on top for the price!
review_text: You can not beat these for the price. I compared these to my friends Bose QC 35 noise cancelling headphones and these work better! The sounds quality at high volumes could be a little cleaner, but it works great for what I need. These are great for mowing the lawn and blocking the lawnmower noise from my zero turn. My other set of over the ear Anker headphones (Soundcore Vortex) need to be at basically full volume to hear the music while mowing. These do not need to be thanks to the hybrid active noise cancellation. I also really like the folding design of these. I wish they came with a better case though as I plan on taking them to Europe. A hard case would be better for a carry on plane ride to protect them. That is really my only big complaint. The bass up feature is neat and works pretty well if you are into that. The battery life is amazing on these as well. I have had them for a week with daily usage and no charges yet! Overall I am very satisfied with the Anker Soundcore Life Q20 headphones. If you are in the market for a good quality set of noise cancelling headphones you will not be disappointed with these.

Pros: Packaging is done very well. The product is well protected. The package contains all necessary accessories. The design is clean and functional. No unnecessary style elements. The ear cups are comfortable for long time use. Headband is robust and easily adjustable. Speaker enclosures rotate 90 degrees for storage. Sound quality is quite good and works in noisy environments. Cons: Noise reduction is adequate for the price point, but does not blank out all ambient noise. Instruction booklet is very basic. No operating detail is provided. However many languages are presented for world-wide acceptance. Pairing with Bluetooth was initially confusing, but subsequently simple and fast. Instructions were not clear. My overall opinion of the Soundcore Life Q20 is very positive. I have had other Bluetooth headsets in the past and have had quality difficulties. Having tested the Soundcore Life Q20 for a month of almost daily usage, I have found them to be reliable, easy to use with good sound reproduction quality and well made. Of particular favorable note, the ear cups are securely attached to the speaker units. With other brands in this price range I have had occasions where the foam ear cups simple fall off, especially when the headset is packed in a backpack or carry bag. These foam ear caps stayed in place. The speaker units swivel 90 degrees to lie flat for packing. The recharging time is normal and recharge recovery is quick. It is to be noted that the interior of the ear cups are market L and R, Left and Right, for orientation. A nice little feature for first time users. Construction is all plastic, except for a portion of the easily expanded top headband. That portion appears to be stainless steel. Headphone controls are found on the bottom of each ear cup. The Left cup has the ON/OFF button as well the NC button which enables noise reduction. The Right ear cup has a Play button in the center with a + to advance to the next track and a - to go back, These are easily manipulated by touch. The headphones appear to be able to withstand normal handling and travel jostling, but i would not let them be used as a toy by young children. Within this price range, the Soundcore Life Q20 is a good choice.

review_title: Good, budget friendly noise canceling headphones.
review_text: Let me preface my review by stating that my other pair of over the ear headphones retail for $300+, so the bar I'm comparing these to is set quite high. I've used the Soundcore Life Q20's for about a week now. Overall, they are a great value for the price. My initial impression was very good. The packaging and presentation is on par with what I have come to expect from anker products. They came with and audio cable for wired input, and a micro USB cable for charging. They fold flat for storage, as seen in the packaged photo, and have a cloth carry bag. The headphones are light, which means they are comfortable to wear for extended sessions, but does not contribute to the impression of quality. The volume, power, and active noise canceling buttons are intuitive to use and function well, but also feel flimsy. Sound quality is OK, but sounds muddy. They have a bass boost feature, but still lack deep bass. The highs lack crispness and clarity. Overall they aren't perfect, but they do a decent job of everything at a relatively budget friendly price. I wouldn't hesitate to buy them again at the current $60 price.

The sound quality on these speakers is really good, but they don't get very loud. Generally, when I'm listening to music, I want headphones whee I can turn up the volume as much as I can tolerate. With these, I could have the volume up max, and it still wasn't very loud. I don't always like to listen to my music loud either. It's just that these don't get all that loud. The quality of that sound was amazing though. I think these would be better suited for kids, that way they aren't listening to music too loud. The noise cancellation was pretty neat. I had never experienced it before, but when you're in a car and turn these on, it kind of makes it calm and peaceful inside. It's such a neat little feature. I think I like these headphones more for the noise cancellation than I do for listening to music. The price isn't horrible, but considering these don't go as loud as I would like, it's not something I would go out of my way to buy. The Bluetooth feature worked well for me, and I never experienced any drops during the time that I used them. Overall, these aren't a terrible headphone, they just lack some oomph. If you're looking for a wireless headset for your kids though, then these are a better option.

Pros: great battery life, low price Cons: noise cancellation is decent but not great, ear cups trap heat I fly a few times a year and commute ok public transit most days. I have a nice pair of IEMs that I use for long haul flights but prefer wireless headphones for my regular commute. These headphones do a decent job reducing train & ambient noise but you can still hear the outside world (it's a good amount quieter, but definitely still there). Another minor issue with these - when I wear these headphones for more than 2 hours at a time, my ears get a little sweaty. This isn't a problem on airplanes (because it tends to be so cold) but out and about I did notice it. On flights my in ear monitors do a better job blocking out the engine noise and are much better at blocking out voices (especially crying infants, which the soundcore Q20 isn't great at blocking). Still, the Q20 is good enough that it's going to replace my expensive IEMs on shorter flights. Battery life is probably the strongest argument in favor of the Q20 - I've been using them for my daily commute + a roundtrip flight over the last 2 weeks and still am going off the initial charge. I've never owned wireless headphones with such good battery life. Overall given the $50-60 price point, sound quality is slightly better than I expected, noise cancelling is decent but not great, and battery life has really impressed me. If you're looking for quiet on long flights this probably isn't your best bet, but for daily use and the occasional <4 hour flight, these are great.

review_title: Love Anker Products, and these do not dissapoint
review_text: Ordered these based on Brand, and was not disappointed. I have tried a few different models of headphones, and these are very comfortable, sound amazing ( great bass ) and do a very good job of noise cancellation. The battery life has been great, have never run out of charge, listening for a few hours at a time, and they seem to hold their charge well ( as do all of my other Anker products. ) I now have 3 Sound Core audio products, Speaker, IN EAR headphones and now these. I almost forget that they are battery powered as the charge is so great. The Sound of all 3 devices has kept me coming back each time. These headphones are not "the best of the best" but for the price-point, they rule the kingdom. I am very satisfied with these headphones, and would suggest them to all my friends.

review_title: Life Q20 Review: Good ANC, Average Bass, and Basic Flaws.
review_text: I ordered the Life Q20's mainly for the ANC. I didn't want to spend 300 dollars for a pair of Bose, or even 350 for the new 700s, so I knew there would be sacrifices at this price point. It was really between these and the Mpow H12's with Hybrid Noice Cancellation, which are also 60 dollars (but on sale for 40 right now). Really the only reason I picked these was because they work with Google Assistant, look slightly nicer, and because I know Anker's earpads are really comfortable, but didn't know how the Mpow's felt. FEEL: That said, these are really comfortable headphones. I used to own a pair of the Crusher Wireless's from Skullcandy and these are wayyy more comfortable. The memory foam is superb and the headband doesn't crush at all. The biggest issue with the cuffs is they get hot. Now I do sweat more than an average person but these get a little too hot. If I'm walking it's not to the point where I'll sweat, but it gets near that tipping point. ANC: The ANC on these isn't bad. It obviously doesn't compare to Bose's ANC, but honestly, when you're already listening to music, you can't really hear much. I play football and there's a huge speaker in the room where the team plays music. If I turn on the ANC and turn the volume up, I really can't hear it that well, if at all. I can't say how they perform on flights, as I'm not going to be on one any time soon, but if I do fly I will update for sure. FLAW (ANC): One big complaint (and, unless returning wasn't a hassle, would be a deal breaker for me), is that there is an issue with wind. When it's windy outside and the ANC is on, the Mics will pick up the sound of the wind and try to counter it, which makes a windy noise on the inside. It's not extremely loud but it's loud enough to notice, and it's also simply not acceptable from a company like Anker, at a price point of 60 dollars. It's not a big gripe but it's one that simply shouldn't exist for a pair of headphones at this price point. SOUND QUALITY: I'm not really an audiophile, and I do like bass so I am slightly biased, but these aren't bad. The soundstage is lacking, and the bass is heavily lacking in the bass up feature (honestly it just seems to muddle the treble and mids). It's good for anybody who just listens to music for chilling and fun. If you're an audiophile I'm sure there are issues with it. FLAW (SOUND QUALITY): One huge flaw with these headphones is how they sound wired! Goodness it's incredible how they go from $60-$100 sounding headphones straight down to $15-$20 headphones. You HAVE to turn ANC on in order for the headphones to sound how they would with Bluetooth on. Without the ANC (and a charge for it) they sound awful, which is a major flaw because the whole point of a cable is to use it without draining the battery... All of that in perspective, I would probably recommend the Mpow H12's over these. Those have incredible reviews and I haven't seen anything about the wind issue (which again, is basically a deal breaker. It definitely would have been if I'd known beforehand). The only issue is those don't have any support for Google Assistant or Siri or Alexa.

review_title: The best reasonably priced noise canceling headphones out there.
review_text: The sound is excellent and I haven't run the battery down in the two weeks I'be had these headphones. I use them so I can hear the TV whole I grind my coffee and they cut out the grinding perfectly.

review_title: Excellent headphones with good features such as noise cancelling and basa
review_text: The soft foam cushions allow me to wear them for a long time during my trips. The noise cancelling is great for walking around NYC streets. The sound quality is great. The flexible headband fits nicely

review_title: Best bargain and a battery-life champion
review_text: I bought these because I couldn’t rationalize buying a pair of noise canceling headphone in $200-$300 range. Turns out, these satisfied my want! The best part is the battery life. If it’s made by Anker, you know it will last as long as you need.

review_title: Great headphone. However the noise cancellation could be better.
review_text: Loyal Anker customer here. Bought different items (chargers, powerbank, speakers, headphones..) from this Brand. Satisfied with most of purchases. This is a new production after Life 2. It looks same as life 2, but added Hybrid Active Noise Canceling which you will find on "SoundCore Space NC". I don't have either Life 2 or Space NC to compare the noise cancellation performance. But I have tried Bose Q35II and Sony WH1000XM3 in the store. I mainly use this headphone in the office to block the sounds from other people's discussion or conference calls. For this purpose, this headphone doesn't meet my expectation. Although it mostly eliminates all the background noises (like fan, air conditioner,...) but I still can hear my colleague's voice with ANC on. This is my personal opinion, based on my use case. Other reviewers seem to like it, because they want to be aware when someone talk with them. It all depends on your situation. Other than the ANC could be better, nothing else can be complained, especially at this price point. Just like other Anker products, the build quality is great. I have it for two weeks now, never experience any connection issue. Decent sound quality. It comes with a soft case, which I don't mind. If you have any experience comparing its noise cancellation performance with Anker Space NC or MPOW H10, please let me know.

review_title: Great Headset for a Great Price
review_text: I was looking for a noise-canceling pair of headphone but didn't want to spend hundreds of dollars. I read the reviews on several different pairs and settled on the Anker Soundcore Life Q20 because of an online coupon and good reviews. In addition to the fact that they are noise-canceling, battery life is a huge improvement over all my other wireless earbuds and headphones. While the noise-canceling isn't 100%, it drastically lowers the volume of any nearby noise allowing a much better listening experience for videos, podcasts or sometimes just trying to meditate. I have only been able to use them a couple of times a day and have yet to need to charge them after the first day. I am impressed by this set of headphones for the price I bought them for. I recommend the Anker Soundcore Life Q20 if you don't need complete noise-canceling and don't want to spend hundreds of dollars for a good wireless headphone.

Really compact and noise cancelling worthy of more expensive headphones. I was surprised how much bang for the buck these provide. I bought them for my wife so use at the gym and she loves them. Her only wish is that they would fold all the way down for storage. They are still more compact than other brands similar offerings which makes them perfect for her. She hasn't had any battery issues, we've charged them once and she uses them for about just under an hour every few days, it's been almost 2 weeks since then and that's using Bluetooth with her iphone.

We bought this product mainly for casual listening and whenever we do some traveling. The sound quality is fantastic and build quality is up there with the pricier headphones. For what it costs and how it sounds, this is a great buy.

review_title: Look good, sound good, but doesn't poor design
review_text: Not an audiophile so the sound quality is just fine for me. Noise cancelling works well. Great price. Controls are decent. My biggest complaint? Who designed these to fold FLAT instead of designing them to be collapsible? They barely fit in the bag as is, making them collapsible you could have put them in a hard case so they would be better protected and taken up less room. Major oversight. But hey, they're still a decent pair of noise cancelling BT headphones.

Very comfortable to wear for long periods of time while listening to training videos, YouTube and more. The sound quality is clear without being so sharp it hurts my ears. I like being able to hear what I'm listening to without competing with the other sounds around me. I especially like that it has the capacity for 30 listening hours. I can't confirm how long it takes to charge, because I plug it in before I go to bed. Well worth the selling price.

I own a pair of Bose QC 25 headphones which I enjoy thoroughly. They are my go to headphones in almost every situation whether studying at home or on a plane. This noise cancellation with the Bose QC 25 is good, but not as good as the QC 35. However, the sound quality of Bose is fantastic in my opinion and I have several additional pair of Bose headphones that I use at the gym and as a back up pair. I've even converted my wife to Bose quality. That being said, i needed a pair of headphones to use at work to drown out the noise while working at the computer and I didn't want to take the risk of my Bose being damaged or growing legs and walking away. Unfortunately I have very high quality standards but a limited budget, so I tried to find something that would meet my needs while not breaking the bank. Enter the Anker Soundcore Life Q20 headphones. Bought from Amazon at around the $50 mark, I figured that the Anker quality would make them durable, but I wasn't convinced that the sound quality and noise cancellation would even compare to my Bose. I can wholeheartedly say that I was wrong. The build is actually better than my Bose. Very solid and yet modernly styled and not bulky. While the sound is not Bose by any means, it is exceptional for this price point. Not a big fan of the bass boost as it makes the totality of the music more subdued and somewhat detracts from the overall quality. Without the bass boost, I found that the sound quality is well rounded and has enough punch so that it doesn't feel lacking at any range. The noise cancellation is quite good, but doesn't rival the QC 35, which to me is the standard for higher end headphones. With just the noise cancellation on it does make a noticeable difference in quieting conversations in the office around me, but still allows overly loud conversations to seep through. With noise cancellation and music together, the noises fade away and are almost undetectable. The included carry bag is decent quality, but seems a little small for the headphones and cords as the headphones seem to slightly stick out of the top of the bag. With the draw string pulled together, it tucks the headphones away in the bag but has a tendency to compress the ear cups, which I believe over time may limit their life span, resulting in a need for replacement. Overall, while not $300 headphones, they are surprisingly robust in almost every facet and make a great choice for those on a budget who wish to enjoy some of the benefits of the higher priced headphones while not breaking the bank.

First I want to address the amazing battery life on these! I used these headphones while working every day for two weeks for two hours daily and haven’t charged them yet. The sound quality is amazing! The cushion on the ears are super comfortable too. These are also very easy to connect! All around these are great headphones!

Full disclosure, I'm not exactly a full-blown audiophile. However, I couldn't seem to find anything resembling a more audio-quality focused review for these on head-fi and other sites, so I figured I'd do a brief(ish) sound overview. Going into this I wasn't expecting much, and to be honest, I didn't get much. But I'll try to convince you why that's okay, and these are still a pretty good buy, imo. The following is for the "normal" EQ mode, which in reality isn't all that normal whatsoever. Tests were done using lossless FLAC files through a mid-range DAC. Whether or not you believe in burn-in, I did let them play for a little while before doing any testing. Starting at the low end, it's a bassy mess. Sub-bass is actually alright, maybe slightly overtuned. Mid-bass becomes a terribly bloated, muddy monstrosity and to add insult to injury, it's boosted to appalling amounts. Very unpleasant. Lower mid to midrange follows similarly and sounds slightly closed. Moderate to severe congestion issues with bass, and it even bleeds a bit into higher mids and presence range as well. As a result, vocals are less than desirable. Everything sounds relatively laid-back even at high volume. Also, there's an AWFUL sibilance somewhere around 2k-3kHz, leading some hi-hats to sound almost like white noise. The highs beyond that are just decent. They can get a little glassy and bright but they hold up nicely otherwise. Overall, these headphones have a complete disregard for balance (which I expected) and hold a very typical V shaped signature. Clarity is barely passable, and soundstage is unimpressive. After a bit of EQ, they do sound better, but of course, that is up to the user. No type of aptX seems to be supported. Audio performance is slightly (yet noticeably) better wired, but Bluetooth connectivity is great and hissing is kept to an impressive minimum. The bass boost function is there, but why anyone would choose to use it is beyond me. The ANC is alright; it doesn't do the sound quality any favors. So far the review been pretty negative, but keep in mind the price and intended purpose. For a pair of $60 Bluetooth cans from a company that's basically still a baby in the audio industry, these are honestly not bad. What they lack in sound they make up for in build quality, comfort, and ease of use. I bought these to use on the subway, walking down the street, etc. and they perform very well in those environments. They were never meant to be studio monitors. The ear cushions are very soft and offer many hours of listening before getting uncomfortable/hot. Media and volume controls are tactile and easy to use. Construction is solid - creaking/microphonics at the hinges are not present when moving around. If you're using these outside or near other people, chances are that the surrounding environmental noise will cover up the sub-stellar audio quality anyways, even with the ANC on. At the end of the day, I'd still recommend these for anyone who wants a comfortable and convenient pair of wireless headphones. They feel very nice, and even smell kind of nice right out of the box.
Umm longer life than the earbuds

These Soundcore headphones are amazing. I use them every day. I’ve been listening to audiobooks via the Audible app for a couple of years, and before I got these headphones, I would just turn up the volume on my iPhone while I cleaned. This was a decent solution, but it didn’t always help to hold my concentration and/or it was difficult to hear over the vacuum or when I was washing the dishes. Likewise, when I was working on writing, I was easily distracted if my girls started to get raucous. But no more! Now I slap my headphones on, and I can clean for a long time before I get distracted, and my writing is also more productive because I can block out all the background noise. Earbuds start to bother my ears after awhile, so I really do appreciate the over the ear style. The ear cups are so soft; they’re comfortable to wear, and it’s easy to forget that I’m even wearing them. They really do block out all the noise, and the sound quality is great. I’ve paired these headphones with my iPhone and with my MacBook with no difficulties. They pair almost instantly whenever I want them to- I never have to fiddle with the settings like I do with some of our other Bluetooth products. The battery lasts for a long time. I end up charging these every couple of days; the headphones will tell me the battery life by saying “Battery high/medium/low” when I turn them on. When I do charge them, it’s a fairly quick process, so I’m waiting around forever- which is ideal. I would absolutely recommend the Soundcore headphones. I’ve become much more productive since getting them; having a short attention span is very frustrating, so finding a solution that increases productivity has changed my life for the better.

review_title: Eye Watering Full-range Fullness of Sound
review_text: I'm astounded with this headphone. How is it possible to package such a superior product for only $60. I have 17 headphones (I collect headphones as a hobby, but they have to perform at a high level to become part of my collection.) I prefer these as my go-to set over nearly all others including the top line Bose, Sony, B&O, B&W and other outstanding brands that I collect. You never see me around town without headphones -- seriously. You will love these. I hear all frequencies including an awesome, deep thumping bass. The fullness of sound will make your eyes water in amazement. You'll never want to take them off. Other functionality is on par as well.

review_title: Even at the "low" price these are not worth the money
review_text: People have been raving about this company for a few years so I finally decided to try a product. It was exactly as I feared: the noise cancelling barely does anything and the audio quality is trash compared with a set of headphones that is only marginally more expensive. If you're going to use your heaphones for 5-10 years like I do, don't bother skimping and buy something much better than these junkers. The only positive is that they are comfortable. EDIT - After this review, Anker reached out to me and have gone above and beyond to ensure customer satisfaction. These headphones are still not the ones for me, but I no longer have any reason to try to dissuade buyers from trying an Anker product. If it works well for you, awesome. These ones aren't for me, but they've spent a lot of time helping me and trying to find the right model that will more closely fit my needs. This is an actual quote from me to their customer service: "Thank you so much for all you're doing, I've never seen such a high level of commitment to customer satisfaction!"

review_title: Loud popping sounds during jolting movement
review_text: I was excited to get these at a great discount, but that excitement waned quickly. I'm pretty sure my passive shooting earmuffs block more sound than these things do with their ANC. I mean there was clearly a difference between when it was active versus not, but I could still hear a whisper a few feet away. Still, I could've lived with it for the price. Where it all went wrong was when I put them on before jogging down my stairs. Every step caused a loud popping sound. I thought maybe it was the connection at first, pulled out my phone, disconnected, and reconnected. Same thing. I turned off the ANC, and no more popping. Turned ANC back on, did a couple small jumps barely leaving the ground, and there it was again. I then shook my head back and forth and the popping occurred every time my head changed direction. It didn't seem to take much to recreate the issue. Needless to say, they'll be going back.
Lite, comfortable, reduces outside noise and sound great. What more could you want?

Updated Anker reached out to me and promptly shipped a replacement. The new headphones do not have any problems described below. My partner is very happy now. I still think the audio quality is just ok but with the build quality problems solved, this is a solid 4.5/5 product. If you already trust the brand, they definitely deliver in terms of price/performance, battery life, a polished look, and superb customer service. Original review below. As with most Anker products, the battery life is great and I've had no connectivity or pairing issues. Microphonics are poor though. Every time you move your head, you can hear the creaking plastic. Another major regular annoyance is that there's a shrill, loud pop sound every once in a while. This is with multiple android and Apple devices. I've not been able to find the exact cause but it has happened only when noise cancellation is on. My partner who isn't comfortable with in-ear earphones, leaves noise cancellation off for the most part because she is very sensitive to such random loud sounds. I would rate these 3.5/5 overall and these would be perfect if they could fix the above mentioned 2 problems.

Got these headphone for the bass and noise cancelling. The noise cancelling is just ok not the best and the "deep bass" is just missing. I've had headphones in the past that have deep bass and you can definitely hear it, but I just don't seem to hear it in the Soundcore Life Q20. The Soundcore headphones sound like regular headphones with simply good audio quality. I definitely feel the description is bit misleading by saying that the headphones provide "deep bass". It should really be removed from the description. I've decided to keep them only because they were inexpensive, the physical quality is good, and audio quality is good as well.
I don't exactly have an extraordinarily small head, but even at the tightest setting these things are loose on my head and will slide off at the slightestmovement,

***UPDATE*** At first I was not pleased with the purchase but Anker reached out to me and said they had an updated version coming out and wanted me to try them. Huge difference for my needs and at this price point. I am satisfied with this purchase and I got to keep the old pair for backup. Works great at the office to drown out any background office noises while listening to music. However when you are using them in a louder environment it does knock out some of the background noise but then the music level is not quite loud enough. It sounds like the music level is at 60% and the background noise is at 40%, if the ratio was 80/20 these would be awesome headphones. For me though I didnt purchase these for office use so they are not what i was hoping for.

review_title: Great Sound and Noise Cancelling is very good.
review_text: These headphones are very comfortable sound great and really work well. Great bluetooth range easy connection. The sound canceling is amazing. Anker makes good products..

review_title: Amazing Price, Battery and Good Sound Quality
review_text: Just got these and have to say they are quite good for what they cost. I am comparing these with my Parrot over-ear headphones which I have used for years and these have a much better battery life and love how lightweight these are. The sound quality and ANC isn't as good as the Parrots but they are very acceptable. Pros: Highly cost-effective for what you get. Battery life Low weight Long-range BT Comfort Cons: SQ could be better ANC isn't the best, but at this price you cant complain. No side swipe buttons Hard buttons when pressed you can hear through the head phone Not as loud as I would prefer Overall, these were a good choice for my long haul trip to AUS coming up. I will save my Parrot headphones with their 4-hr battery life for quick flights.

The Q20 headphones are easy to use, have good audio quality, are decently comfortable and have great battery life. The only codec that seems to work is SBC (presumably AAC works on iOS), although this information is not detailed in any documentation with the headphones or on their website. I use these with a portable audio player, not a phone, so I don't know how the microphones for voice calling work. I can say that the noise cancellation is very good for the price. It doesn't cut out as much high-frequency (mostly voice) noise as some other models, but it deletes a majority of the low-frequency and middle-frequency noise that is common on streets or airplanes. Noise cancellation is easy to toggle on and off, but takes a second holding the button so you're not likely to toggle it accidentally. The power button similarly takes a second or two to toggle. Bluetooth pairing is done via that power button as well, by holding it for a few seconds longer when turning the headphones on. The extra bass mode is decent, if you're into that sort of thing. I generally use the volume and play/pause buttons and little else, but I tested it and it works. For noise cancelling headphones that you won't worry about pampering, there aren't a lot of options out there. I think the Cowin models are the main competition. The Anker has slightly better noise cancellation, slightly better battery life, and that bass boost mode, but no AptX or other high-bitrate Bluetooth codec. Depending on what's important to you, the two are very similar. The Anker model folds flatter, but the Cowin comes with a more durable travel case. Really, you can't go wrong with either.

review_title: Best noise cancellation headphone at the price point
review_text: Good sound quality with meaty bass and excellent noise cancellation. Noise cancellation does not change the sound quality at all besides dip the volume level a bit. An excellent and responsive customer support is the icing on the cake while buying Anker products.

I am in the process of preparing for a trip from ATL to SF, and I was somewhat looking for a good pair of headphones, Wireless, and i received a notification about the Anker Soundcore Life Q20on sale. for under 50, they are a good deal. I do have a couple of issues, and I can update my review in regards to use on a 5+ hour flight. - - They don't fit well, I would like to have the ability to adjust the headset more comfortable on my bald head. I have to use the device in is default configuration; which makes me wonder how others are using them with hair. The cups fit snuggle OVER my ears, and seem to seal well enough to block outside notice. -\+ The sounds is light on the bass, which i like. I listen to 60/70 rock and R&B, and there was no loud thumping bass.
Easy setup and sounds really good. These get lite usage, but I could see them getting used more and more. Very comfortable.

review_title: Great for the money, pretty great period!
review_text: Had a pair of Bose NC headphones years ago that I really liked, but were hot/heavy to wear. Fast forward to now; bought these for occasional use at work/travel. Overall, really good sound quality (not highest tier, but plenty good for casual Bluetooth listening). The most pleasant aspect to me however is how nice these feel on the ears. They don't make me feel warm & sweaty like many other over ear cushions have previously. I've seen some reviews mention a somewhat cheap feel to these, but I disagree; they're not made out of metal, & you shouldn't expect them to feel like they are. A solid purchase, especially at the coupon price of ~ $50.

Trusting other ANKER products, I thought these would be a strong purchase. But I was pretty disappointed. Few good qualities; battery my life is great and the ear cups are soft for comfort. And then the number of poor qualities. - They fit rather large, not a complaint just fact, so they sat lower on my ear. - The sound quality is average at best, bass is good but everything else is muddy. - Noise cancellation is not the greatest. - Worst of all, the Bluetooth will randomly disconnect. First and second time I used them, didn’t have a problem, but the third time they would disconnect and turn off every 15 minutes, despite the battery being fully charged. Not sure if this is a outlier defect but I will definitely be returning these. If you have $60 to spend for a product that you want to provide the most basic function, these are your headphones.

I had a pair of Philips noise-cancelling headphones in the very early days of ANC (mid-2000s), and they gave me a headache. I saw the 20% off deal on these, and thought I'd take a chance and give them a spin. As others have noted, they're good but not great headphones. The construction feels less-than-sturdy, but I have a hard-shell headphone case if I need to transport these. I tested out the ANC on DC's subway system, and I was pretty impressed with how much sound it dampened. The sound quality is good, but the bass enhancer feature isn't for anyone but the most devoted bassheads. The fit is fairly comfortable, although as others have noted they aren't cool when walking around on a hot day. I may eventually graduate from here to the Sonys or a pair of my favored brand of headphone, Sennheiser, but this is proving to be a worthwhile foray back into ANC headphones.

review_title: Great pair of affordable noice cancelling headphones.
review_text: I had been looking for an inexpensive pair of noice cancelling headphones. My original budget had been $100, but then I found these. I have an Anker Soundcore speaker which I absolutely love, and love their USB to lightning cables. For $50 on sale, I just had to give them a try. I'd definitely recommend these. Yes the plastic does feel a little cheap, and not being able to charge and use at the same is unfortunate, but I think they're more than worth their price. The active noise cancelling works very well, the battery life is decent, and the audio quality is more than adequate. The high volume limit does seem a bit quiet to me, but maybe I've just lost some of my hearing. I tested these out while cutting the grass on an older louder riding lawnmower. I could hear the music great and the mower was reduced to a quiet hum. I'll be curious to see how the battery life is next time I fly. Hopefully it will last through my long haul from PA to Alaska. I will have to update when I find out.

review_title: Great feel, soild build, solid battery.
review_text: The headphones feel great for long term wear. The build feels solid and the battery life so far is excellent.

For context of this review, I also own the Bose Quiet Comfort earbuds and use them pretty regularly. First, the negative out of the way - they feel like cheap plastic to me. If you're playing with the buttons while they're on your ears you can hear how thin the manufacturing is in places. Kinda distracting, but you get used to it fast. Second negative is that they sit a little tight on the ears for a closed design, which also takes some getting used to. The positive - I have loud coworkers, and I sit pretty close to them. When I needed to concentrate previously, I'd grab my earbuds and crank music as loud as I could take it to drown them out. That mostly worked just fine, but I was probably doing some damage to my ears in the process. These headphones completely changed the game for me. Even with the ANC turned off, they still isolate pretty well. Once you turn on ANC, everything fads into the background and nothing cuts through. Not even my super aggressive typing, which I'm pretty sure also annoys my neighbors. :) Sound quality is solid. Not the BEST I've ever heard, but really solid. If you're listening over bluetooth, you have some compression artifacts already so complaining isn't allowed. Sure, they're not like 500 dollar studio monitor headsets on a nice amp, but for 50 bucks they're great. A little bass heavy maybe, but solid mid ranges too. Things I didn't test: Microphone / voice calls Battery life (it's long. I just charge it daily when I leave the office and I don't think I'm gonna run out of juice.) Bottom line is that these are a killer value, do a great job, and are absolutely worth the price.
Connected them to my work laptop and the sound keeps dropping and it get staticky. At this point they useless. I will give it a few more days but will most likely return them

review_title: Noise Cancellation is easily the best in its price range
review_text: The noise cancelling headphones I have been able to reference this against are the Plantronics Backbeat pro 2, Mpow H5, Anker life 2, and Anker space nc. My conclusion is that there is nothing close to the price/performance that you get with the Anker Q20. The noise cancellation on the Q20 is easily the best of the headphones I'm comparing, and much, much better than the the Backbeat Pro 2, which costs more than double the Q20. The sound quality is quite similar to the Anker Life 2, while the noise cancellation is similar to the Anker Space NC--the Q20 is really the best of both of Anker's previous attempts. Of all the headphones I'm comparing, I like the control ergonomics, overall comfort, and sound quality of the Backbeat Pro 2 the most, and the fact that the Backbeat Pro 2 will auto play/pause when you remove the headphones from your head is a really cool feature. Furthermore, the Backbeat pro is the coolest on my ears of any of the headphones I'm comparing. However, when purchasing these headphones, my primary goal was to have decent noise cancelling, and these fit the bill while still providing good overall sound quality, albeit a bit more bass heavy and less transparent sounding than the Backbeat Pro 2, which was definitely my favorite of the bunch as far as sound quality goes. Regardless, in the sub $100 price range, nothing seems to come close to the overall value of these. They have excellent battery life, noise cancelling that seems to be better than anything else in the sub $200 range, comfortable build, and fantastic sound quality for their price segment. The only area where they seem to fall short is breathability--they do feel fairly hot on the ears after awhile, especially compared to the Backbeat Pro 2 or the MPow h5. Having said that, breathability is the ONLY area where I find the MPow h5 to be superior to the Anker Q20.
Not good, very low volume.

I'm very impressed with the sound of these headphones, especially for the price. It has some good bass to it and the sound is crystal clear. It's noise canceling so it's best that you not wear it while walking outside if you want to hear your surroundings. It's best to wear them while you're going to be inside. These sound almost as good as the beats headphones that I used to have but these feel more comfortable on my ears. I wore them for hours without irritation. The battery life is long too. My new favorite headphones.
I like Anker brand, but the headphone light bass,

for one thing: it emits a harsh brief rush of static if your head moves abruptly down. That's not exactly clear, so for example if you run down the stairs you will get a few highly irritating noises straight into your ears. This is definitely not a good thing. Otherwise I'm pretty happy with them: good sound, great battery life, and the controls are well thought out.
Awesome headphones! No complaints!
My husband loves it especially the big bass sound and noise cancelling function.
Easy to use

review_title: Very good value, long battery life, some progress yet to be made.
review_text: Good value, works well, but as with all noise cancelling headphones, they do not completely silence loud voices, but can make it possible to work under bad circumstances, and concentrate completely under moderately noisy conditions. Quality of audio is good enough. Bluetooth has a significant delay when working with Siri, and siri frequently misunderstands spoken commands using this headset. Transmitted audio from phone conversations with this device are of low quality even in a silent room. The headset is fairly comfortable for long wear, with no pain points forming even after a few hours with them on. They function well within their limitations.

Preface: This review is based off needing these for the office and around home—not gym/workout. That said, I have yet to come across a better deal than this for my purposes for the below $100 price range. Expectations were low to begin with—as it is unfair to compare these to a product such as the Bose QuietComfort series—but were definitely exceeded! For this price, you really do get a lot for your money (customer service, build quality, materials, sound quality, battery life, many features, and even nicer packaging than this product probably deserves). Again, when judging it as a product in this price range, it's tough to really "complain" about anything. A few specific points: - Bluetooth 5: Have had no connectivity issues. - ANC: It does the job. Is it perfect? No. But it is a big help getting those ambient noises at a significantly lower volume. Has made listening music at work a much better experience. - Comfortable: Ear cushions are very soft. I'm also able to wear glasses with these, if needed, vs. my Audio-Technica ATH-M20x, which is impossible. - Sound: Sound quality is good and much better than I expected. Whereas I prefer a more neutral EQ, these are a slight bit mid/bass leaning, even more so with ANC enabled. That said, I don't use the BassUp feature, as it makes the listening experience too muddy for me. Would like an option to disable the voice prompts when enabling/disabling features, but that's more a personal preference. - Phone Calls: Glad I can go from listening to music to a phone call without having to remove the headphones. It just works. Enough said. - Convenience: Many on-board buttons make using these headphones an even better experience, eliminating the need to always refer back to my device. The battery life is also very generous. I debated for a while whether to purchase these or save for the Bose QuietComfort and am very happy I went with these and saved a lot of money. For my simple needs, these do an exceptional job!

review_title: If could do 4.5 I would. Good price, good noise cancelling, good sound
review_text: I've had the same pair of headphones for 6 years now and have used them on and off. They weren't noise cancelling however and I recently moved into an office space that people make a lot of calls so I couldn't focus. I took a risk with these just because they were cheap and I have been a fan of Anker products. And I am impressed. Obviously you are not getting the same noise cancellation as the big dogs like Sony and Bose, but for the price, it is pretty good. One time during the switching of songs I hear a co-worker on the phone, but while the song was playing I didn't even realize he was on the phone. So overall, good for the price is the name of the game. You won't be getting the best of anything, but they are comfy, cheap, and work for what I need. Bumping down one star because the connection can be a little wonky with my Macbook Pro at work. Keeps pausing, works perfect with my phone however.

Wow these feel so comfortable and have a really long battery life and noise cancellation is very good while sound quality is a beast,Bass boost is so impressive that the headphones VIBRATE and that's how you know these are the best headphones for under 100$ hands down!! !
Not the best headphones. NC just ok. Sound quality could be better. But for the price I think is a considerable choice.

review_title: Good quality and comparable with the big brands
review_text: Great quality headset. Excellent performance too. It works well with its aux cable and also as bluetooth.
They don't cancel the noise as much as I thought they would.

review_title: Good noise cancelling for most background sounds with good overall quality!
review_text: Good quality headphones with good noise cancelling. Good for use while flying eliminating the background noise of the engines. Doesn't really eliminate people's voices, but lessons the voice level. I like that you can still use them as regular headphones for music if unpowered/low battery. The battery lasts no problem for a 5 hour flight.

These are the best headphones I've ever had. The sound quality is way better than beats. They are super comfortable. The only problem is that they are not durable. Even though they are not durable they are still the best headphones I've ever had. These are a definite buy

I have never owned or used any noise-cancelling products before. That said, I read a lot of reviews of different products so I could formulate realistic expectations. Everything is relative, and I'm sure that headphones costing $300+ probably before better than these, but for what I paid I am thrilled. These exceed my expectations by leaps and bounds. I listen to quiet, ambient "chill" or EDM music during my work day. These allow me to listen at a very quiet level, while the ANC filters out the fan on my desk, and most of the background noise of other people. Yes, you can still hear intermittent noise like voices and phones, but these do help, and they are far more effective than the ear buds I was using. If the music was louder, I might not hear any other noises, but I like keep my music very low just as background. These help me focus on my work, but don't completely block out all awareness. I'm not an audiophile, so I can't give detail on the sound quality, but they are excellent for their purposes. I don't fly much, but I do have a trip in a few months and will be taking these and I expect they will do a decent job of cutting out ambient plane noise.

review_title: Probably the best ANC headphones for that price
review_text: Pros: - Price - ANC works as expected - Physical buttons Cons: - I wish there were an ambient noise mode
Too large for my head. Did not adjust small enough.
Great product at a great price.

I bought these to replace my Sony WH-1000XM3 after my dog ate them. They are 80% as good for 25% the price! The noise cancelling isn't as good as the Sony and they could be louder, but these are perfect for me to leave at work. I bet Anker could match the Sony directly for about $99.
I have used it for several days now, and till now the battery life is great, sound is perfect .. the noise cancelling isnt that high but it still works fine

review_title: Excellent NC Cans - especially for the Price
review_text: Dang! Read a review over on Gizmodo saying these were the best NC over the ear headphones for under $100. I'd say they are better than that! Great noise cancelling - no trouble hearing movies and music either in the airport or on the plane. Even better, they do well enough in a woodshop with a dust collection system running, and occasional bursts of powertools, that I can listen to music there without having to turn the volume up so loud that it defeats the purpose of NC - saving my hearing.

review_title: One of the few $50 purchases that has overhauled my quality of life
review_text: The only other products that come close are a good pillow, good underwear, good beer, and allergy spray. My daily bus commute is nice enough, but loud—I get to work with my ears ringing. Wearing these has changed everything; riding the bus now feels a little like watching a silent movie. I understand from the other reviews that the quality of the noise canceling could be better on more expensive headphones, and there are certainly some noise artifacts that get introduced when I run loud water or a loud truck passes, but it's barely audible over a podcast or audiobook and it's still vastly less distracting than the noise of the real environment. UPDATE After daily use for several months, typically at 1+ hours of listening per day, these headphones remain among the most important devices in my life. Some more specific critiques I can make now that I have used them more: * They have significant noise artifacts when I am walking outside, but only as they jostle. * They do poor work reducing the higher-pitch noises on a plane, to the extent that I found myself preferring to have them off. * They are not wildly comfortable after several hours of wear, but remain fine for commuting use.
